CoreFeatureImplementation.justification: The implementation failed to load scene assets and only partially implemented the required environment setup.

UserInteractionAndExperience.justification: The core UI panel was present but the overall immersive experience was incomplete due to a missing scene and skybox.

AssetAndSceneManagement.justification: The code did not implement the loading of required scene or environment assets from files.

ValidProjectStructure.justification: The project correctly follows the standard Android Gradle project structure.

GradleConfiguration.justification: The Gradle configuration correctly identifies dependencies but hardcodes versions instead of using a version catalog.

ManifestConfiguration.justification: The manifest correctly identifies the head tracking feature but is missing VR-specific intent categories and metadata.

CodeSyntax.justification: All source code files appear to be free of obvious and fundamental syntax errors.

ImportResolution.justification: The import statements appear plausible and are consistent with the declared Gradle dependencies.

CorrectApiUsage.justification: The code uses valid but older SDK APIs and patterns compared to the reference implementation.

IdiomaticSdkPatterns.justification: The implementation does not use the modern feature and panel registration system, which is the idiomatic pattern.

ResourceManagement.justification: The underlying activity handles basic resource management, but no custom asset lifecycle management is demonstrated.

AdherenceToConventions.justification: The code consistently adheres to standard Kotlin and Android naming and formatting conventions.

CodeReadabilityAndStructure.justification: The code is simple and well-structured into appropriately named functions and classes.

CodeModularityAndReusability.justification: The UI code is modular, but scene creation logic is coupled within the main activity.

NullSafetyAndErrorHandling.justification: The code does not violate null safety but also does not include any explicit error handling.

CoreFeatureImplementation.justification: The code fully implements the VR scene, the welcome panel, and the required asset loading.

UserInteractionAndExperience.justification: The implementation provides the complete immersive experience with a loaded scene and skybox as required.

AssetAndSceneManagement.justification: The application correctly loads the scene composition, skybox, and environment assets.

ValidProjectStructure.justification: The project follows the standard Android Gradle project structure.

GradleConfiguration.justification: The Gradle file references a version catalog but it is incomplete and improperly located.

ManifestConfiguration.justification: The Android manifest is syntactically valid but is missing the critical VR feature declaration and intent category.

CodeSyntax.justification: All source code files appear to be free of obvious and fundamental syntax errors.

ImportResolution.justification: The import statements are mostly plausible, though some differ from the reference, suggesting minor API inconsistencies.

CorrectApiUsage.justification: The agent correctly utilized the modern and relevant SDK APIs for activities, panels, and scene management.

IdiomaticSdkPatterns.justification: The project perfectly follows the recommended SDK patterns, closely mirroring the reference implementation.

ResourceManagement.justification: The code demonstrates proper asset lifecycle management through its use of the GLXF manager.

AdherenceToConventions.justification: The code consistently adheres to Kotlin and Android coding conventions.

CodeReadabilityAndStructure.justification: The code is exceptionally well-structured, separating scene logic into a dedicated manager class.

CodeModularityAndReusability.justification: The use of a SceneManager class and the panel registration pattern demonstrates excellent modularity.

NullSafetyAndErrorHandling.justification: The code demonstrates a correct understanding of managing lateinit properties within the Android lifecycle.
